According to Barney Kessel, Oscar Moore (1916 - 1981) practically invented the role of the guitarist in small combo jazz.  We donÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t know if this is true as is often the case with claims of this kind.  What we do know however is that MooreÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s role in shaping the sound of the Nat King Cole Trio, the first drummerless trio in jazz, was of paramount importance.  It is Oscar MooreÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s guitar we cherish on these 1937-1947 immortal sides the Cole Trio cut for various small labels.  Unfortunately, MooreÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s solo career after leaving Cole never took off and he cut just a handful of records for the Verve and Tampa labels before retiting from the music business altogether and ending up working as a bricklayer in Los Angeles - a cryinÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ shame.  This 1954 recording for the Tampa label with Carl Perkins amply demonstrates what an enormous talent and elegance in delivery Moore possessed. ~itsartolie
